questions.question: Match the following tissue macrophages with respective organs: 1. Kupffer cells a) liver 2. Dust cells b) spleen 3. Hofbauer cells c) lung 4. Littoral cells d) placenta 5. Mesangial cells e) kidney
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-a, 2-c, 3-d, 4-b, 5-e Explanation: Name of the macrophage Tissue/ Organ Microglia Brain Dust cells or Alveolar Macrophages Lungs Kuppffer cells Liver Littoral cells Spleen Mesangial cells Kidney Hofbauer cells Placenta Osteoclasts Bone Type A synoviocyte Synovium Langerhans cells Skin Histiocytes Connective tissue Sinus histiocytes Lymph nodes Reference: Robins and Cotrans Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, pg. 97 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/ articles/PMC4553254/#:~:text=Thus%2C%20macrophages%20take%20different%20names

questions.question: Which type of macrophages predominantly contributes to tissue repair and resolution of inflammation in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease complicated by pneumonia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) M2 macrophages Explanation: The predominant type of macrophages contributing to tissue repair and resolution of inflammation in this patient's lungs is M2 type of Macrophages, also known as Alternatively activated macrophages. Macrophages are of two types based on their activation: M1 activation M2 activation Also known as “Classical macrophage activation.” “Alternative macrophage activation.” Stimulus for activation Microbial products (e.g., endotoxin); TLRs (Toll-like receptor) T cell-derived signals (e.g., IFN- γ ), Foreign substances (e.g., crystals). IL-4 IL-13. Releases Reactive oxygen species (ROS), lysosomal enzymes, nitric oxide (NO) and Pro-inflammatory cytokines TNF- α IL-1; IL-12; IL-23 Anti-inflammatory cytokines IL-10 TGF- β Function Microbicidal destroys pathogens and amplifies inflammation. Terminates the inflammation and promotes tissue repair (fibrosis). Reference: Robins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition,, pg. 98

questions.question: Which of the following statements about granulomas is incorrect?

options.A: Granuloma formation is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction
options.B: IFN gamma is an important cytokine involved in the process
options.C: CD8+ is the type of T lymphocytes involved in this process
options.D: Epitheloid cells in granuloma are modified macrophages

questions.explanation: T cells. CD4+ T cells help activate macrophages and other immune cells, promoting the formation and maintenance of granulomas. CD8+ T cells are more commonly associated with cytotoxic responses against infected or abnormal cells rather than granuloma formation. Options A , B and D are correct statements. Reference: Robins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, - Pages 100, 101

questions.question: Which sequence accurately identifies lymphocytes, epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and caseous necrosis in the image given below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) d, b, c, a Explanation: Epithelioid Cells (label b): Activated macrophages transform into epithelioid cells, resembling epithelial cells with pink granular cytoplasm and indistinct cell boundaries. Lymphocytes (label d): These surround the clusters of epithelioid cells, forming a collar. They play a vital role (mainly T cells) in the immune response to antigens presented by the epithelioid cells. Langhans Giant Cell (label c) : These multinucleated giant cells are derived from the fusion of activated macrophages and are often found in the later stages of granuloma formation. Caseous Necrosis (label a): In granulomas associated with certain infections like Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a central zone of caseous necrosis may form due to hypoxia and free radical-mediated injury, resulting in the characteristic cheesy appearance of the necrotic material. granuloma - caseous necrosis" data-author="" data-hash="1775" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/R91a9bxRPsSaiqAx4mDz1742966405.png" /> Reference: Robins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, - Pages 100, 101

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presents with a persistent dry cough, shortness of breath, and bilateral enlargement of the lymph nodes in her chest, incidentally detected on a routine chest X-ray given below. Physical examination reveals fine crackles in her lung bases. Pulmonary function tests show reduced lung volumes and a decreased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide. Which type of granuloma is commonly associated with the histopathological findings in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Naked granuloma Explanation: The given clinical presentation suggests Sarcoidosis, a systemic granulomatous disorder characterized by non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid histiocytes and multinucleated giant cells without associated fibrosis or necrosis. The characteristic histopathological feature of sarcoidosis is "Naked granuloma” which refers to the “absence of lymphocytic collar.”

questions.question: Which of the following is not a physiological giant cell?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Langhans cells Explanation: Langhans giant cells are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of macrophages. They are often seen in the granulomas formed in response to certain infections or foreign substances. They are typically found associated with tuberculosis. They are characterized by a horseshoe-shaped arrangement of nuclei within the cytoplasm Osteoclast (Options A) , Syncytiotrophoblast Options B) , and Megakaryocytes (Options C) are physiological giant cells. Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/345064687_Giant_Cells_A_Review

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent subcutaneous nodule on his forearm. Biopsy reveals the presence of multinucleated giant cells within the lesion, as shown in the accompanying HPE image. Further analysis indicates a central zone of lipid-laden macrophages surrounded by a wreath-like arrangement of nuclei. Which type of giant cell is most likely to be observed in this scenario?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Touton giant cells Explanation: The multinucleated giant cells described in the scenario, with a central zone of lipid-laden macrophages surrounded by a wreath-like arrangement of nuclei, are characteristic of Touton giant cells. Giant Cell Type Description Seen in Touton Giant Cells Multinucleated giant cells with a central zone of lipid-laden Macrophages are surrounded by a wreath-like arrangement of nuclei. Xanthogranuloma, xanthoma, fat necrosis Reed-Sternberg Cells (Option B) Large, binucleated or multinucleated cells with prominent nucleoli, often with an "owl's eye" appearance (pink nucleoli) (RS cells- also seen in DLBCL, owl’s eye appearance- also seen in CMV infection) Hodgkin lymphoma Warthin-Finkeldey Giant Cells (Option C) Large, multinucleated cells with irregularly distributed nuclei and a foamy cytoplasm. May contain intranuclear and intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions. Measles (Rubeola) infection Langhans Giant Cells Multinucleated giant cells with nuclei arranged peripherally in a horseshoe-like or semicircular pattern. Tuberculosis, Sarcoidosis

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a routine elective surgery for the removal of a benign skin lesion on her forearm. The procedure involves making a small incision, excising the lesion, and closing the wound with sutures. Which of the following statements accurately describes wound healing by primary intention in this scenario?

options.A: Myofibroblasts play a significant role in wound contraction.
options.B: The wound is associated with large tissue deficits.
options.D: The wound is expected to heal with minimal inflammatory response.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) The wound is expected to heal with minimal inflammatory response. minimal tissue damage. Therefore, wound healing by primary intention is expected and is characterized by a minimal inflammatory response. Myofibroblasts play a significant role in wound contraction, which is a characteristic feature of wound healing by secondary intention (Option A) . Large tissue deficits are more characteristic of wound healing by secondary intention. (Option B) Granulation tissue formation is minimal in wound healing by primary intention. (Option C)

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a raised scar on his chest. He reports that the scar has been gradually increasing in size since he had a minor injury in that area about a year ago. On examination, the scar extends beyond the original wound margins and appears firm and raised. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the scar on the patient's chest?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Keloid Explanation: The most likely diagnosis for a raised scar on the patient’s chest is Keloid characterized by abnormal and excessive growth of scar tissue that grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress. It typically appears firm, raised, and extends beyond the margins of the initial injury. Keloid formation seems to be an individual predisposition, and it is more common in African Americans. Sternum is the most common site for Keloid formation. Treatment can be done by intralesional injection of steroids like Triamcinolone. Hypertrophic scar : (option A) While hypertrophic scars are also raised, they typically remain within the boundaries of the original injury. They may regress over time and are less likely to recur after treatment compared to keloids. Exuberant granulation tissue(Option C) Exuberant granulation tissue,

questions.question: Which of the following cell types is classified as stable cells in terms of their proliferative capacity and turnover rate?

options.C: Stratified squamous epithelia of the skin

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Endothelial cells in blood vessels Explanation: Endothelial cells in blood vessels are examples of stable cells. Classification of cells based on the proliferative capacity and turnover rate: Labile cells Stable cells Permanent cells These cells are continuously being lost and replaced by maturation from tissue stem cells and by the proliferation of mature cells. Labile cells include hematopoietic cells in the bone marrow (Option B) and the majority of surface epithelia (Option C) They are quiescent and have minimal proliferative activity from progenitor cells. They divide only when required but limited regeneration compared to labile cells. Stable cells constitute the parenchyma of most solid tissues(liver), endothelial cells (Option D) , fibroblasts, and smooth muscle cells. These cells are considered to be terminally differentiated and nonproliferative in postnatal life. Permanent cells include Neurons (Option A) and cardiac and skeletal muscle cells. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic Basis of Diseases 10th ed. Page 103

questions.question: A 55-year-old man undergoes a minor surgical procedure to remove a small skin lesion from his forearm, and the wound is meticulously closed with sutures. Three days after the surgery, he comes to the OPD for review. Which event of the wound healing process is typically observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Replacement of neutrophils by macrophages Explanation: Events in wound healing: DAY EVENTS DAY 0 Platelets and Fibrin form blood clots. (Option A) DAY 1 Blood clot remains and recruitment of neutrophils (acute inflammation). (Option B) DAY 2 Blood clots remain; neutrophils accumulate followed by thin epithelial layer formation. DAY 3 Chronic inflammation sets in, and macrophages replace neutrophils. (Option C) Granulation tissue begins (blood vessel formation starts) DAY 5 Maximum granulation tissue (Maximum neovascularization) Collagen bridging starts (Option D) DAY 21(3RD WEEK) Maximum collagen deposition (Type I collagen.) Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of diseases 10th ed. page 108

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding wound healing is true?

options.A: The wound regains 20% of its normal strength by 1 week.
options.B: The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks.
options.C: The wound regains its original strength eventually.
options.D: The initial collagen formed in the process of wound healing is Type-1 collagen.

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks. Explanation: At the end of one week, wound regains 10% of its original strength. (Option A) The wound regains 70-80% of its normal strength by 12 weeks. The wound never reaches 100% of its original strength . (Option C) The initial collagen formed in the process of wound healing is Type-III collagen. (Option D) It is replaced by type-1 collagen (strong and has the highest tensile strength). In the end, the ratio of type-1 to type-III collagen is 4:1. Reference: Robbins and Cotrans Pathologic basis of diseases 10th ed. page 108.
